bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 25 (Thursday, February 11, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ROE of Tennessee:H.R. 4545.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2: The Congress shall havepower to dispose of and make all needfull rules andregulations respecting the terrority or other propertybelonging to the United States; and nothing in thisConstitution shall be construed as to prejudice any claims ofthe United States, or of any particular state.[Page H775]

item.name: Wilderness and natural areas, wildlife refuges, wild rivers, habitats

summary.text:
Tennessee Wilderness Act of 2016

This bill designates specified federal lands in Cherokee National Forest in Tennessee as wilderness and as additions to existing components of the National Wilderness Preservation System.

bill.title: Tennessee Wilderness Act of 2016

item.title: To expand the Big Laurel Branch Wilderness and Sampson Mountain Wilderness in the Cherokee National Forest in the State of Tennessee, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Conservation and Forestry.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
